channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 全球最先进的芯片生产商台积电即将在日本开设第一家制造工厂。本月早些时候，它宣布了在附近建立第二家工厂的计划。这与这家台湾巨头在美国陷入困境的扩张形成了鲜明对比： 👇
item.description:
The world’s most advanced chip producer, TSMC, is about to open its first fabrication plant in Japan. Earlier this month it announced plans for a second plant nearby. That contrasts with the Taiwanese giant’s troubled expansion in America: https://t.co/RsttqqbPxp 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 在一些人看来，澳大利亚的野马是牧场文化的最后遗存，这种文化在高原地区受到保护时就已灭绝。但是，随着野马数量的增长，政客们开始打击野马。
item.description:
To some, Australia’s brumbies are a last vestige of a ranching culture extirpated when the high country was protected. But as their population grows, politicians are cracking down on the wild horses https://t.co/TTKNs2wd2g

Photo: Getty Images pic.twitter.com/wPl0iv9QXF

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 中国首席思想家在美国发现的缺陷
item.description:
The flaws that China’s chief ideologue found in America https://t.co/EdlZOHy0bM

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 对于美国大法官来说，棘手的问题是如何理解社交媒体公司的概念。它们是否类似于报纸，可以完全控制其版面上出现的内容？还是更接近于电话公司或快递服务公司？ 👇
item.description:
The tricky question for America’s justices is how to conceptualise social-media companies.

Are they akin to newspapers, which have total control over what appears in their pages? Or are they closer to phone companies or delivery services? https://t.co/9DDU6cTGpk 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普的审判会如何左右选民？
item.description:
How might Donald Trump’s trials sway voters? https://t.co/OM3uGiBFL9

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 唐纳德-特朗普威胁要将他在 2018 年挑起的贸易战升级，对中国商品征收 60% 或更高的关税。这会对中国企业造成多大伤害？ 👇
item.description:
Donald Trump has threatened to escalate the trade war he started in 2018 by imposing tariffs of 60% or more on Chinese goods. How badly would that hurt Chinese firms? https://t.co/pZg4UPc6y8 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 一种 "涡轮增压超级猪 "正在加拿大大草原上肆虐。当它们南迁时会发生什么？ 👇
item.description:
A breed of “turbocharged superpigs” is raising hell on the Canadian prairies. What could happen when they move south? https://t.co/fmH5wtgRx7 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 随着弗拉基米尔-普京发出威胁，唐纳德-特朗普酝酿撤回对欧洲的支持，所有人都认为欧洲需要在武装力量上投入更多资金。但人们较少认识到，这种转变将带来多大的冲击。
item.description:
With Vladimir Putin issuing threats and Donald Trump musing about withdrawing support, everyone agrees that Europe needs to spend more on its armed forces.

What is less widely recognised is how wrenching the shift will be https://t.co/zThYY2TIrP 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 27, 2024

item.title: 原来真正的 "常识 "是一种难以捉摸的东西 👇
item.description:
It turns out truly “common” sense is an elusive thing https://t.co/537UlYQZw9 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

They will shape the drama of this year’s presidential election https://t.co/fdmT8wCAw3 ⬇️

The Palestinians’ new prime minister faces a nightmare https://t.co/t11RYzZPd0 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 股市到处都在刷新纪录。这种飙升是可持续的，还是修正的前奏？ 阿尔韦托-米兰达
item.description:
Everywhere you look, stockmarkets are breaking records. Is the surge sustainable or the prelude to a correction? https://t.co/FzbcfhuNJb

Illustration: Alberto Miranda pic.twitter.com/USNypF9ZU1

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 日本和美国政府都迫切希望扩大国内芯片生产，并寻求外国公司的帮助。那么，熊本的庆祝与亚利桑那州的头痛形成鲜明对比的原因是什么呢？ 👇
item.description:
Both the Japanese and American governments are eager to expand domestic production of chips, and are seeking the help of foreign firms. So what explains the contrast between celebrations in Kumamoto and headaches in Arizona? https://t.co/GX3jrwJGNl 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 许多人在离开大学时都背负着沉重的债务，获得的学位也只是一个无关紧要的、教学质量很差的学位。他们被骗了，没有为更好的生活做好准备👇。
item.description:
Many leave university loaded with debt and equipped with a degree of peripheral relevance that has been taught badly. They are being ripped off, not prepared for a better life https://t.co/n61F6MOJCE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 腐败是问题的核心。监狱工作人员敲诈勒索盛行，贿赂可以买到更好的牢房。1843 》杂志探究了俄罗斯刑事系统的内部运作。
item.description:
Corruption lies at the heart of it. Racketeering by prison staff is endemic and bribery can buy you a better cell. But those who refuse to pay get “broken”—beaten or tortured.

1843 magazine explores the inner workings of Russia’s penal system https://t.co/cmLDFHeWQk

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: "监狱系统的目标......是打垮人们，摧毁他们的人格，为民众接种反自由的疫苗。"俄罗斯最受瞩目的政治犯之一向《1843》杂志提供了古拉格集中营生活的独特见解
item.description:
“The goal of the penitentiary system…is to break people, to destroy their personality and to vaccinate the population against freedom.”

One of Russia’s highest-profile political prisoners gives 1843 magazine a unique insight into life inside a gulag https://t.co/XFeSOgTwkR

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 您能猜出世界上最昂贵的城市吗？ 👇
item.description:
Can you guess the world’s most expensive cities? https://t.co/N39Zh5JeDw 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 林赛-霍伊尔爵士对国会议员福祉的关注使他在议会中异常受欢迎。但这并没有提高英国人对政治家的信任--现在，这已经危及到他的职业生涯 ⬇️。
item.description:
His concern for MPs’ well-being made Sir Lindsay Hoyle unusually popular in Parliament. But it has done little for Britain’s trust in politicians—and now it has jeopardised his career https://t.co/4MbX6ablxA ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.description:
It is just not that fulfilling https://t.co/4qWBgRBCOe 👇

A reading list to better understand the history of the Israel-Palestine conflict https://t.co/TNSDF3yE4J 👇

item.title: Mistral 推出了最新的大型语言模型，并与微软达成了协议。我们来认识一下这家希望与 OpenAI 👇一较高下的法国初创公司。
item.description:
Mistral has unveiled its latest large language model—and a deal with Microsoft. We meet the French startup hoping to take on OpenAI https://t.co/ThTvWWdtyi 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 美国医生的收入为何如此之高 👇
item.description:
Why doctors in America earn so much https://t.co/YQRPz7K1EN 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 尼基-黑利总统竞选活动的曲折、似乎不可避免的消亡，反映了美国共和党中日益濒危的里根派的命运👇。
item.description:
The tortured, seemingly inevitable, demise of Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign mirrors the fate of the increasingly endangered Reaganite wing of America’s Republican Party https://t.co/jKWdjRdEe2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 拥抱可爱的霍比特人和男孩英雄，软化了意大利后法西斯主义的边缘，就像乔治亚-梅洛尼自传中的喷绘肖像一样有效。@john_hooper 发现，曾经的特立独行如今已成为无价的宣传品。
item.description:
Embracing cuddly hobbits and boy heroes softens the edges of Italian post-fascism as effectively as the airbrushed portraits of Giorgia Meloni in her autobiography. @john_hooper discovers how what was once an idiosyncrasy is now invaluable propaganda https://t.co/lXXAVqYPOU

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 英格兰国民健康服务机构的一个信托基金认为变性妇女的牛奶是 "婴儿的理想食品"，从而引发了争议 Anna Kövecses
item.description:
A trust in England’s National Health Service has stirred controversy by concluding that milk from transgender women was the “ideal food for infants” https://t.co/XPNmBT0Nve

Illustration: Anna Kövecses pic.twitter.com/frYC41B1xu

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: "我能直言不讳吗？我想我之所以加入这个小组，是因为你们都不会做 PowerPoint。"根据一个几乎真实的故事改编的办公室情景剧：👇
item.description:
“Can I be candid? I think I am on this group because none of you can do PowerPoint.”

An office drama based on an almost-true story: https://t.co/WlCgh7kJJb 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 土耳其是继美国和英国之后，剧本节目销量最大的国家。它们不仅在中东，而且在欧洲和拉丁美洲也很受欢迎 👇
item.description:
After America and Britain, Turkey is the biggest seller of scripted shows. They are popular not just in the Middle East but also in Europe and Latin America https://t.co/DlbsWiTSnE 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 播客之名刚刚诞生 20 年，就已成为主流。打开 Apple、Spotify 以及越来越多的 YouTube，你可以找到约 400 万个播客节目，从刑满释放人员到公爵夫人，应有尽有。下一步是什么？ 👇
item.description:
Just 20 years after they got their name, podcasts are mainstream. You can open Apple, Spotify and, increasingly, YouTube to ﬁnd some 4m shows by everyone from ex­-convicts to duchesses. What’s next? https://t.co/l1ocUUaMJL 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 自俄罗斯两年前入侵以来，已有约 31 000 名乌克兰士兵丧生。有多少俄罗斯士兵丧生？这五张图表说明了巨大的损失👇。
item.description:
Some 31,000 Ukrainian troops have been killed since Russia invaded two years ago. How many Russian soldiers have died? These five charts illustrate the enormous losses https://t.co/pd0WXHzt7a 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024

item.title: 金丝雀码头正在重塑自我。现在，伦敦人不再每周五天通勤，金丝雀码头区正在扩大其吸引力，以满足那些寻求居住或休闲场所的人们的需求。它能成功吗？ 👇
item.description:
Canary wharf is reinventing itself. Now that Londoners are not commuting five days a week, the district is broadening its appeal, to accommodate those seeking somewhere to live or let loose. Will it succeed? https://t.co/IVyWqaJEHI 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) February 26, 2024
